data.title: Frances Langford dies at 91
data.meta_description: Frances Langford, whose steamy rendition of I'm in the Mood for Love captivated American soldiers when she was part of Bob Hope's overseas tours in the second world war, died yesterday at the age of 91 at her home in Jensen Beach, Florida.
data.text:
Frances Langford, whose steamy rendition of I'm in the Mood for Love captivated American soldiers when she was part of Bob Hope's overseas tours in the second world war, died yesterday at the age of 91 at her home in Jensen Beach, Florida.

Langford, a recording artist, radio star and actress from the 1930s to 1950s, joined Hope's troupe to boost wartime morale at military bases and hospitals in Britain, Italy, North Africa and the South Pacific. She also entertained new generations of soldiers in Korea and Vietnam. The 5ft (1.55m) tall singer became known as the Sweetheart of the Fighting Fronts.

Her trademark was I'm in the Mood for Love, written for her for the 1935 movie Every Night at Eight. Langford appeared in 30 Hollywood movies. She played herself in her final film, The Glenn Miller Story, in 1954.

She was also known for her role as the insufferable wife, Blanche, in the 1940s radio comedy, The Bickersons.

She said decades later that entertaining the troops "was the greatest thing in my life."

Born in Lakeland in April 1914, Langford was discovered by bandleader Rudy Vallee. After the war, she met outboard motor heir Ralph Evinrude. They married in 1955 and moved to Jensen Beach.

In 1994, she married Harold Stuart, assistant secretary of the air force under President Truman.
